STATEMENTS BY THE CHIEF MINISTER
(Committee on Minimum Standards of Livelihood)


    The Chief Minister (Mr D. S. Marshall): If it please you, Mr Speaker, Sir, I have to announce that the Government has set up a Committee to enquire into the field of possible government action to establish minimum standards of livelihood among the people. The full terms of reference are:

    "To examine and report upon the desirability and feasibility of Government action to promote the establishment of minimum standards of livelihood for the people of Singapore, including the institution of unemployment insurance, the prescribing of minimum wages, either generally or in selected industries, and the extension of existing measures of social security through pensions, provident schemes or otherwise."

    The Committee, Sir, will be presided over by the Economic Adviser, Sir Sydney Caine, and the following have agreed to serve on it: 

   Mr Cheong Hock Hai.

   Dr. Kai-Loo Huang.

   Dr. Lim Tay Boh.

   Mr S. Rajaratnam.

   Miss J. M. Robertson.


The Secretary, Sir, will be the Assistant to the Economic Adviser, Mr P. A. Wilson. In addition, the Committee will be assisted by the International Labour Office expert, Mr Brocklehurst, who is already working with the Ministry of Labour, and it is our hope, Sir, by an expert from Australia on minimum wage legislation.

    The principal organisations of employees and employers, as well as all interested members of the public, will be invited to submit their representations to this Committee.

Economic Advisory Unit


    I have furthermore to inform hon. Members that Government has set up an Economic Advisory Unit which will consist of the Economic Adviser, Sir Sydney Caine, and two full-time assistants. The purpose of this Unit is that it should give advice to the Government on general economic policy, on the programme of capital investment, and on the broad economic aspects of social policy.

Column: 963



    It is now, Sir, as you are aware, the normal practice, both amongst our immediate neighbours and in other countries of the world, for advisory work of this nature to be entrusted to a unit entirely independent of the ordinary executive departments, and it is that precedent which we seek to follow.

    The Economic Advisory Unit is to be attached for the present to my office, but it is my hope, as our constitution develops, that some other arrangement will be found preferable, and I have in mind its attachment to the future Minister for Finance.

    Members of the Economic Advisory Unit will be advisers of all Ministers concerned with economic policy, and it is proposed that this Unit should work to a Ministerial sub-committee of the Council of Ministers on economic matters. To assist in the preparation of subject for discussion and decision by Ministers, a Committee of officials from the principal interested departments is also being formed. The Economic Advisory Unit itself will have no powers of executive authority or control, but it will work in closest contact with existing departments, and it is the intention that it should be kept small in size and should make maximum use of the statistical and other technical facilities of existing departments.

    Among the matters which we expect the Economic Advisory Unit to examine in the immediate future are the various recommendations of the International Bank Mission, including the details of the proposals for the Central Bank, whose establishment we are very anxious to expedite, Sir; the establishment of an Industrial Development Corporation; the formation of a long-term development programme; the broad nature of future budgetary policy, and measures for the establishment of minimum standards of livelihood.

    It is our intention that the Unit should keep in close touch with those concerned with economic policy in the Federation.

Standing Order on Press


    Now, Sir, to come to more domestic matters: I have to inform hon. Members, who probably are aware of it from

the newspapers, that I have received a telegram from the Commonwealth Press Association, when it held its conference in Canberra, which reads as follows:

    "I AM ASKED TO INFORM YOU OF FOLLOWING RESOLUTION UNANIMOUSLY ADOPTED TODAY BY COMMONWEALTH PRESS CONFERENCE ON MOTION WICKREMESINGHE OF CEYLON SECONDED BY DEVILLIERS SOUTH AFRICA STOP THIS CONFERENCE REPRESENTING NEWSPAPERS FROM ALL PARTS OF THE COMMONWEALTH IS CONCERNED AT THE NEW REGULATION ADOPTED BY SINGAPORE ASSEMBLY UNDER WHICH A REPORTER MAY BE EXCLUDED FROM THE ASSEMBLY IF THE SPEAKER CONSIDERS A REPORT HE HAS WRITTEN TO BE UNFAIR STOP THIS CONFERENCE DOES NOT QUESTION THE RIGHT OF THE ASSEMBLY TO CONTROL ALL WHO FREQUENT ASSEMBLY HOUSE BUT POINTS OUT THAT FAIRNESS OR UNFAIRNESS IS INCAPABLE PRECISE DEFINITION AND URGES THAT THE REGULATION BE REDRAFTED TO CONFORM WITH THE PRACTICE WHICH HAS LONG PROVED SATISFACTORY IN PARLIAMENT OF WESTMINISTER".

    It was signed, Sir, by "H. E. Turner, Secretary", to which I replied:

    "YOUR TELEGRAM NINTH NOVEMBER RE MOTION WICKREMESINGHE OF CEYLON WHO REFERENCE OUTSTANDING ORDER ADMISSION PRESS IS REPORTED TO HAVE STATED THAT HE HAD NEVER HEARD OF SUCH A RULING OPERATING IN ANY PARLIAMENT INSIDE THE COMMONWEALTH AND IT WAS MOST UNUSUAL AND UNFAIR TO INVEST THE SPEAKER WITH SUCH RIGHT WOULD INFORM YOU STANDING ORDER 19 (3)OF CEYLON IS SIMILAR NO INFORMATION AVAILABLE THAT MR.WICKREMESINGHE COMPLAINED OF HIS COUNTRY'S LAWS FURTHERMORE FOR THE RECORD STANDING ORDER 61 OF JAMAICA STANDING ORDER 134 OF GOLD COAST STANDING ORDER 73OF NIGERIA STANDING ORDER 69 OF TRINIDAD AND TOBAGO STANDING ORDER 22 OF MAURITIUS ARE SIMILAR IN CHARACTER ALSO OUR STANDING ORDER IS NOT NEW BUT HAS BEEN IN FORCE FOR MANY MANY YEARS FINALLY THE STANDING ORDER WAS ADAPTED BY A CLERK OF THE HOUSE OF COMMONS FROM A MODEL CONSTITUTION EVOLVED BY OFFICIALS OF THE HOUSE OF COMMONS INCORPORATING THE TRADITIONS OF WESTMINSTER STOP YOUR REQUEST BEING REFERRED SELECT COMMITTEE ON STANDING ORDERS MEANWHILE I

REGRET YOU SHOULD HAVE ATTACKED SINGAPORE WITHOUT CHECKING EASILY ASCERTAINABLE FACTS".

    Sir, I have since then received representations from the Singapore Union of Journalists, and with your permission, Sir, since this affects the House, I shall read the memorandum they submitted:

    "We have called upon you on behalf of the Journalists of Singapore to ask your good offices in seeking the repeal of the order that confers upon the Speaker the arbitrary right to issue cards for admittance to the Assembly hearings and to withdraw them from individual working journalists for what he judges to be an unfair report. In return we offer the co-operation of this Union in drawing up any clause replacing it to ensure fair reporting.

    The Union is non-political. We certainly do not intend to make party capital out of this issue. We are always ready and willing to co-operate freely to our best ability in maintaining the friendly relations between Press and Parliament that are essential in a free Democracy. We would point out that this Union raised the matter in August last when the order was first published and asked Mr Speaker to receive a delegation which he could not see his way to do.

    We ask for the repeal of this clause for three reasons.

    I. No such powers exist in the Imperial Parliament at Westminster where the Speaker is an elected Member, equivalent to those conferred upon the Speaker here who is not elected by the Assembly. We would point out that the Assemblymen are elected, that the Speaker is their servant but has not been elected. Thus an official who cannot claim to be representative is given arbitrary powers to bar the Press from the democratic assembly. This seems to us worthy of Alice in Wonderland.

    II. As framed the clause is in our eyes utterly unfair. The reporter is a servant of his newspaper. What he writes may be and often is altered and presented in a way he cannot control. We strongly urge that if anyone be penalised it should be the editor or publisher and that their remedy is against the reporter as in cases of libel and slander. It might be interpreted in fact as fear to attack the powerful and victimise the weak."

    I think, Sir, he meant remedy is against the proprietor.

    "III. We find no precedent for such powers of judging what is fair and unfair vested in one man anywhere in the Commonwealth save in its most politically backward dependencies, in fact in territories where there is no Trade Union of Journalists to fight the cause of Freedom of the Press. As to Ceylon we believe that you have been misinformed, Mr Chief Minister. Even were you not we

Column: 966

would point out that Ceylon is a country where the working Journalist is deprived of the protection of a Trade Union so that we are the most surprised that it should precisely have been a Ceylon publicist who raised at Melbourne the Issue of Press Freedom on information derived solely and entirely from the organ of a Trade Union of Journalists.

    Finally Mr Chief Minister we feel that a joint statement on future intentions from yourself and from this Union be issued to the world and to the local Press to calm the apprehension that has been aroused. We would urge upon you sir the desirability of handling the whole matter through this Union representative of all the newspapers in every language group in Singapore...".

    Sir, in view of the suggestion that I was misinformed as to the Standing Orders of Ceylon, I sought the assistance of the Clerk of the Assembly and have obtained, through him, from the Clerk of the Ceylon Parliament a telegram indicating that Standing Order 19 (3) of Ceylon is still operative and has been in force for many, many years. Standing Order 19 (3) of Ceylon reads:

    "Mr Speaker may grant a general permission to the representative or representatives of any journal to attend the sitting of the House. Such permission may be revoked it the journal publish a report of the proceedings which Mr Speaker considers unfair".

    This, Sir, is very similar to the provisions we have.

    I think, in fairness, Sir, we should give a little publicity to the actual facts. These Standing Orders of ours were adapted by a Clerk of the House of Commons from a model constitution evolved by the House of Common authorities, and they were brought into force on the 14th of April by His Excellency the Governor under his powers conferred by the Singapore Colony Order in Council. The Council of Ministers themselves were consulted. We were naturally in a great hurry at that time. We wished to hold an early sitting of this Assembly and, apart from making a few alterations, the Standing Orders were accepted. But, I think the House will remember that on the 29th of June this year, I informed the House that the Standing Orders were not wholly adequate, and on my motion the House appointed a Select Committee to make a comprehensive review of all Standing Orders. In fairness to this Assembly, Sir, it has not had an opportunity yet to examine the Standing

Column: 967

Orders, or to take any decisions upon them, because the Select Committee which it has appointed to investigate the matter has not yet made a report.

    You, Sir, as in duty bound, if I may respectfully say so, in pursuance of the requirements of Standing Order 75, made Rule 12 about the admission of the Press, and this is a matter which has passed without comment for many decades now, not only in Singapore but in other parts of the world; and it is more than a little unreasonable that there should have been that attack, both upon Singapore and on you, Sir, as a result of Rule 12 which seems to have been misconstrued. But in view of the nature of the representations received, particularly those of the Singapore Union of Journalists, I have sent them to the Select Committee, and I trust that they will be considered against the background of our own inherent powers to refuse admission to strangers, and also our powers and privileges under the Ordinance which has now become law in this country, It may well be found by the Select Committee that Standing Order 75 is really tautologous, but that is a matter which must be left to the Select Committee to report to this House.

    One final matter on this, Sir. There was an unfortunate attack on you in a local newspaper, issue of the 11th of November. After consultation with the leaders of all Parties in this Assembly, I spoke to the editor and I am happy to report, Sir, that he saw the point immediately and wrote me a letter which I should like to read out to you. This paper is the Singapore Tiger Standard, dated 17th of November:

"Dear Mr Marshall,

    I learnt with regret from you this morning that the Speaker of the Assembly was perturbed by an article appearing in my paper of the 11th of November under the heading "The News As It Strikes Me". I have perused this article in the light of your comments, and I would like to assure you that there was no intention whatsoever of malevolence against the Speaker or your Assembly.

    I would like you to express to the Speaker and to the Assembly my sincere regrets and that of my paper if the said article has caused any distress."

APPROPRIATION BILL


    Order read for resuming adjourned debate - [9th November]:

    Mr G. A. P. Sutherland (Nominated): Mr Speaker, Sir, I had hoped that the secondary armament would be fired at a later date, but with all this rushing to speak, I might as well get started. Mr Speaker, Sir, I should like to state that, in view of the increasing heterogeneity of Parties on the Opposition side, such opinions as I would voice now are free of the influence of any party politics and I am expressing no views but my own.

    Sir, as a banker, I have made it my business in the past to try to understand something of government finance, and I found little to surprise me in the speech of the Hon. the Financial Secretary, which though it emphasised that the Colony's financial position was sound, was nevertheless something of a jeremiad. This is, of course, in the best tradition of Financial Secretaries, and the present incumbent is as jealous a watchdog of government finance as any we have seen. His predecessor uttered grave warnings about the necessity for cutting down on expenditure in Government departments, and I trust the present Government will make every effort to live within its means. Certainly from the number of amendments that appear in the Estimates, it would appear that the Opposition is going to try to persuade the Government into this way of thinking.

    In the figures given on pages 10 and 11 of the Sessional Paper No. Cmd. 28 of 1955 of "Personal Emoluments" and "Other Charges Annually Recurrent" for Education, Medical and Social Welfare, the rise is steep enough in all

Column: 969

consciousness. Yet the Sessional Paper states that during the next five years expenditure on those services is expected to increase with even greater rapidity. This point was given further elucidation by the Hon. the Financial Secretary in his speech, and it appears that even after allowing for the streamlining of the Government machine as a whole, we shall be faced, on the present basis of revenue, with an annual deficit in the region of $40 million in five years' time. Now this is indeed a sobering thought and however unpalatable it may be, it seems obvious that increased taxation is both necessary and inevitable. I do sincerely hope that the attitude of all right-thinking citizens will be a sympathetic one towards Government in its problem - a difficult problem indeed - with the gulf between revenue and expenditure already wide and likely to widen further as the years pass. The problem indeed seems almost to be insoluble. That more money annually must be spent on education, health, and social welfare goes without saying, and someone must foot the bill. Nevertheless, care must surely be taken to see that we do not interfere with business as a whole, and that capital is not scared away from the Colony.

    I trust the House will take heed of the Financial Secretary's warning that the greatest care must be taken not to let the Colony's reserves run too low, and note his observation that the market for local loans is not unlimited in capacity. The market for local loans is indeed the very reverse of unlimited in capacity. There have been occasions recently when the City Council have tried to raise money in local loans, and had it not been for a substantial demand by the Central Provident Fund of the Federation Government, the loans would have met with very poor success indeed. Now, one of the reasons for this, Sir - I could give many - is that there just is not a great deal of money around seeking this particular type of investment.

Column: 970



    To me, one of the most interesting things about the Hon. the Financial Secretary's speech was the uninhibited way in which he told us of the various proposals for increased taxation that had been considered and rejected. We also know, at least to some extent, what we may expect in the future. One would expect a Government, Socialist in background, to introduce increased taxation on the upper income group. I do not quarrel with the principle of placing the burden of taxation on the shoulders of those who are best able to bear it, but no effort should be spared to increase the efficiency of the Income Tax Department to make certain that those people who are capable of paying it do pay it. That there is tax evasion on a large scale seems highly probable. I certainly have heard plenty of talk about it in Singapore over the last five years. The curious thing, Mr Speaker, is how people's moral standards change when it comes to paying Government its just dues. I know quite decent people - you can call them businessmen - who would shudder at the thought of dishonouring a business contract but would do almost anything and go to any lengths to evade paying their tax. All is fair apparently in love, war and dodging income tax! And we all know, Sir, the type of person, usually female, who boasts of having diddled the Customs! While it is good to learn that proposals for joint action by the Governments of Singapore and the Federation "were discussed with cordiality and understanding" - the phrase used - at Kuala Lumpur, it is noteworthy that the Federation Government effectively threw a spanner in the works. In this way, we may see the shape of things to come. I accept unreservedly the Financial Secretary's explanation of why common action in respect of income tax is regarded as essential, but I trust that we are not going to be ruled from Kuala Lumpur.

    Now, Sir, it is only natural that one should feel relieved that the Budget proposals contain no provision for increase of income tax, but that is merely a brief respite, as the Financial Se-

Column: 971

cretary has been at pains to make clear. I have no complaints about the indirect taxes that have been imposed, but I must confess to being astonished that tobacco has escaped. To pass up $19 million of revenue, or potential revenue, when one is scratching around for means of meeting a hefty deficit is, to my mind, quite incomprehensible. There is, to me, something distinctly humorous about the pomposity of the phrase "the Council of Ministers had in mind that intoxicating liquor was, in fact, a luxury. It could not, by any stretch of the imagination, be called a necessity." Well, there are some who would disagree with the Council of Ministers! Now, Sir, I have all the vices - I drink whisky, I smoke cigarettes and - I sing in my bath! But I am as firmly of the opinion as the Council of Ministers is about liquor (why gin escaped, I do not know!) that cigarettes can, in no circumstances, be called a necessity. In the United Kingdom smokers have to pay heavily for the habit, and I do not see why the man-in-the-street in Singapore should not pay a little and help to shoulder the burden by this simple method of indirect taxation. I do not seek an elaboration of Government's brief statement - "It has been decided that it would be undesirable at the present time to increase the tax on cigarettes by even a small amount." I can guess what is in their minds, and I can only regard their attitude in this respect as timorous.

    Mr Lim Choon Mong (Serangoon): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Hon. the Financial Secretary has informed us in his Budget speech that the expenditure for 1956 will exceed the revenue and that the deficit next year is going to be real. This kind of warning from those who prepared previous Budgets has always been too often repeated, and naturally enough we would like to give the warning the discount it deserves. Even then, no matter whichever way our belief is going to be, the fact that we have to face now is that indirect taxation in a number of commodities has increased. We will have to work from the angle that we have just a limited income and how best to spend

Column: 972

it in the interests of the majority of the people. To achieve this aim, we must remember that although there are many claims for development in various directions and from many parts of Singapore, we must sort out what is the most important and what will give benefit to most people, in preference to schemes that will serve an exclusive number of people.

    For instance, if we were to decide whether there should be lighting for a place like Goodwood Hill, where the people travel in large and beautiful cars - they do not, most of them, walk late at night - or lighting for Serangoon Gardens, where the population is denser and more people travel on foot and bicycles, then I think we will have no hesitation in saying that the latter category is more deserving. Of course, money in that direction would have to be voted to the Rural Board. This is just like making a decision with a limited amount of money, whether we should buy cosmetics for our girl or buy a pair of specs for the shortsighted one! You will always come to the right decision, and not throw your money on luxuries. Now, I always believe that schemes like lighting of Goodwood Hill is one that can wait and must wait, and that any money that we can make use of must be diverted to other schemes that are more important and urgent.

    Again it will not be out of place here to mention that, in an austerity programme, those in the Government should set a good example in the need for economy. From the Budget you will see that the Ministers amongst themselves have appropriated sums ranging from $2,000 to $10,000 as entertainment allowances. Drinking champagne and having satay parties are part of the necessary functions of Ministers, but at a time when there is going to be a deficit in the Budget and the whole city is fraught with strikes and unemployment, the cutting down of such parties to a minimum would not be a bad idea. I would rather say that a few Aspros, which are cheaper, might be more helpful in bringing about a more prosperous and peaceful Singapore.

Column: 973



    This is a Labour Front Coalition Government, and we are constantly reminded that it will carry out its Socialist programme. It has promised the people interest-free loans for those who want to build their own houses. As one who might like to take advantage of such an offer, I looked diligently through the pages of the Budget, but, alas, the long hoped-for Government interest-free loan was not there. I was disappointed. That hope, raised so high by the Government, crashed. However, this is not only a bad omission, but there are other events which smashed that crashed hope to smithereens. The Hon. the Financial Secretary has had a word of congratulation for the Rural Board for raising more revenue. Let me acquaint the House of one method of achieving this. Recently I have received many representations from clerks working in the Government, the City Council and the Services, who happen to own houses in Serangoon Garden Estate. They do not get interest-free loans, but they have to pay interest, and it will take them about 15 years to repay the loans by monthly instalments, and yet the Rural Board has deemed fit to exact a higher tax from them by increasing the annual value of their houses. The ground for such increases seems to be that a few houses were let out to Service personnel at higher rentals. Owner residents protested to the Board, but their pleas were ignored. It seems to me that in that locality the innocent must be punished together with the guilty. It is important that wage earners should be encouraged to own land and houses, but if they reckon that they have to pay more in the way of tax when living in their own houses than the rents which they paid for their old pre-war houses, then where does the encouragement come from? Your slums will be harder to clear up, and, of course, there will be more savings for the Public Works Department. That probably will suit the Government in providing excuses for holding up further development plans.

    The tune that is being played now is "no money", and playing that tune you might as well go the whole hog and examine how this tallies with the Budget.

Column: 974

If you refer to the Head: Minister of Health, you will discover that large sums of money are allotted for the purposes of alterations of hospitals. We would like to ask just one question on this. Will such alterations mean a gain in the number of bed space in the hospitals? As far as I am aware today, there have been no such increases in the past, and I do not expect any increase in the future. Instead, you will probably find that the ward is just changed into another shape, and air-conditioning included in certain parts of the ward -

    The Chief Minister: Wholly erroneous.

    Mr Lim Choon Mong: I say here that the people of Singapore are not fastidious. The masses here have endured the heat from time immemorial and they prefer such heat to artificial cooling. In all probability, they would suffer from the discomfort of cold, just as I often do in this Assembly, which is air-conditioned! The first essential of a hospital is to cure, and it is highly preferable that the money to be used for alterations should be utilised to build new district hospitals. The sum involved in this instance is in the region of about $2 million, with no increase in bed space. That money, I should say, is just wasted. Talking about district hospitals, you will have one going to be built next year with a token of $10. Nothing concrete in that.

    Now talking again of savings on expenditure, Government should always make it their business to see that whenever appointments are made, they should be absolutely necessary. I quote you another instance under the Head: Ministry of Health. It would appear, I think, that seven Radiologists are to be appointed. At present you have two. But that hospital has only one General Duty Medical Officer. The other posts are still not filled and you are voting money for new posts. Why is that necessary? I always think that in any set-up - take the case of the Police - if you have six constables, then you have one corporal. If you have so many corporals, then you have one inspector, but you cannot have seven inspectors and one lance-corporal. They do not need so many inspectors to control one lance-corporal.

Column: 975



    Now let me now turn to the Ministry of Education. As a school-master I am drowned daily by pleas from parents wanting to get their children places in schools, primary as well as secondary. It is obvious that Singapore wants more schools - primary as well as secondary. They want more vernacular schools, and they want more trade schools. Now it is the Government's responsibility, in drawing up the Budget, to see that this important aspect of work is tackled. The general level of education of the masses in this country must be raised, and I should say that the greatest treasure that a nation can possess, especially one like us that is striving towards self-government and independence, must be to create a very high percentage of well-educated people. Secondary as well as higher education is what we must have if our dreams for early Malayanisation of the services is to be realised. More schools, more technical schools, schemes and assistance for training within industries are lines which should be adopted as insurance schemes against future unemployment. But what do we find in the Budget? No provision for secondary schools in 1956. That is a very grave omission.

    Even in the direction of social services, what do we find after all the shouting by Government at the top of the roof? Do they do a little more for the under-privileged? We find that the present elected Government is even worse than the previous colonial Government. Whereas a colonial Government had between 1954 and 1955 increased its social service assistance by 50 per cent to youth organisations - and, in this instance, it means the boys' and girls' clubs catering for the under-privileged children of Singapore - the present Government is happy with the figure for 1955, ignoring completely the fact that the number of clubs catering for such youth is about treble. It is very well to sit in an air-conditioned room and claim yourself to be a Socialist fighting for the uplift of the under-privileged and the down-trodden, but I would rather invite you to come out and work amongst them.
